When an &elem; is modified or a &node; is moved, it affects its neighboring &elems;, causing changes in their effective element energy. When the AverageEnergy criterion is applied to a , &oof2; accepts a modification only if it lowers the average effective energy of all of the affected &elems;. If more than one modification is being considered,
This does not mean that all possible node moves are considered for modifiers that choose from an infinite number of possibilities, like does. It only applies to modifiers that sometimes have a finite number of choices to make, such as .
the one that lowers the energy the most is accepted.
The parameter alpha (&agr;) plays a critical role, since it controls how the effective energy is computed for each element. Take the node move shown in for example.

This node move will lower the total homogeneity energy by 0.13 but it will elevate the total shape energy by 0.46. If homogeneity energy and shape energy are to be equally considered (&agr; = 0.5), the move will not be accepted by the AverageEnergy criterion -- it increases the overall energy level. The move becomes possible only if &agr; is greater than 0.8.
